title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: UtilsGGSV provides utility functions plotting R using ggplot2. vignette demonstrates main functions package.
code: library(UtilsGGSV) library(ggplot2) theme_set(cowplot::theme_cowplot())

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: ggcorr function creates scatterplots correlation coefficients overlaid. primary function package useful visualizing relationships groups measurements.

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
code: set.seed(3) response_vec_a <- rnorm(5) response_tbl <- data.frame(   group = rep(letters[1:3], each = 5),   response = c(     response_vec_a,     response_vec_a * 1.2 + rnorm(5, sd = 0.2),     response_vec_a * 2 + rnorm(5, sd = 2)   ),   pid = rep(paste0("id_", 1:5), 3) )  ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid" )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: can display multiple correlation coefficients simultaneously:
code: ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = c("spearman", "pearson") )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: comparing two groups, function creates pairwise comparisons:
code: ggcorr(   data = response_tbl,   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = "kendall" )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: concordance correlation coefficient useful assessing agreement two methods:
code: ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = "concordance",   abline = TRUE,   limits_equal = TRUE )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: Text placement, font size, visual elements can customized:
code: ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = c("spearman", "pearson", "concordance"),   abline = TRUE,   limits_equal = TRUE,   coord = c(0.4, 0.17),   font_size = 3,   skip = 0.04,   pval_signif = 2,   est_signif = 2,   ci_signif = 2 )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: text placement remains consistent even axes transformed:
code: ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::mutate(response = abs(response + 1)^4),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = "spearman",   abline = TRUE,   limits_equal = TRUE,   trans = "log10",   skip = 0.06 )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: axis_limits function helps manage axis limits, particularly useful forcing equal limits axes expanding axis coordinates.
code: data("cars", package = "datasets")  p0 <- ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +   cowplot::background_grid(major = "xy") +   geom_point() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +   labs(title = "Axes unadjusted") +   labs(x = "Speed", y = "Distance")  p1 <- axis_limits(   p = p0,   limits_equal = TRUE ) +   labs(title = "Axes limits equal")  p2 <- axis_limits(   p = p0,   limits_expand = list(     x = c(0, 50),     y = c(-10, 200)   ) ) +   labs(title = "Axes limits expanded")  cowplot::plot_grid(p0, p1, p2)

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: add_text_column function adds text annotations plots consistent positions, regardless underlying axis transformations.
code: data_mod <- data.frame(x = rnorm(mean = 1, 10)^2) data_mod$y <- data_mod$x * 3 + rnorm(10, sd = 0.5) fit <- lm(y ~ x, data = data_mod) coef_tbl <- coefficients(summary(fit)) results_vec <- c(   paste0(     "Intercept: ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, "Estimate"][[1]], 2),     " (",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 1][[1]] - 2 * coef_tbl[1, 2][[1]], 3),     ", ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 1][[1]] + 2 * coef_tbl[1, 2][[1]], 3),     "; p = ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 4][[1]], 3),     ")"   ),   paste0(     "Slope: ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, "Estimate"][[1]], 2),     " (",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 1][[1]] - 2 * coef_tbl[2, 2][[1]], 3),     ", ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 1][[1]] + 2 * coef_tbl[2, 2][[1]], 3),     "; p = ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 4][[1]], 3),     ")"   ) )  p <- ggplot(   data = data_mod,   aes(x = x, y = y) ) +   geom_point() +   cowplot::background_grid(major = "xy")  add_text_column(   p = p,   x = data_mod$x,   y = data_mod$y,   text = results_vec,   coord = c(0.05, 0.95),   skip = 0.07 )

title: Getting Started with UtilsGGSV
text: get_trans function returns transformation objects scales package. adds support additional transformations like higher roots asinh:
code: get_trans("log10") #> Transformer: log-10 [1e-100, Inf] get_trans("asinh") #> Transformer: asinh [-Inf, Inf] get_trans("root_cube") #> Transformer: root_3 [-Inf, Inf]

title: Authors and Citation
text: Miguel Rodo. Maintainer.

code: @Manual{,   title = {UtilsGGSV: Utility functions for ggplot2},   author = {Miguel Rodo},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.5.2},   url = {https://satvilab.github.io/UtilsGGSV/}, }

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: R package providing utility functions ggplot2 plotting.

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: Type: R Package Purpose: ggplot2 plotting utilities Dependencies: ggplot2, cowplot, scales, dplyr, tibble, purrr Tests: testthat (edition 3)

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: R/ - Source code (exported functions, . prefix internal) man/ - Auto-generated docs (edit directly) tests/testthat/ - Tests (use test-{function}.R naming) vignettes/ - Package vignettes

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: Make minimal, surgical changes fix issues Maintain backward compatibility possible Follow existing patterns codebase Add tests new functionality bug fixes Never leave trailing whitespace end lines blank lines Always add blank line headings bullet points

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: IMPORTANT: adding removing exported functions, update _pkgdown.yml reference index include exported functions.
code: devtools::document()  # Update documentation devtools::test()      # Run tests devtools::check()     # Full package check

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: See .github/instructions/ detailed guidelines: r-coding-standards.instructions.md - R code style documentation testing.instructions.md - Test patterns testthat usage package-development.instructions.md - Development workflow

title: Copilot Instructions for UtilsGGSV
text: updating copilot instructions: Keep files 250 lines (max 1000) Use headings, bullets, clear sections Use short, imperative rules long paragraphs Include code examples (correct incorrect patterns) external links - copy info instead vague language - avoid “accurate”, “identify issues” Use applyTo frontmatter topic files path-specific rules

title: UtilsGGSV
text: goal UtilsGGSV provide utility functions plotting R using ggplot2.

title: UtilsGGSV
text: can install UtilsGGSV GitHub :
code: if (!requireNamespace("remotes", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("SATVILab/UtilsGGSV")

title: UtilsGGSV
code: library(UtilsGGSV) library(ggplot2) theme_set(cowplot::theme_cowplot())

title: UtilsGGSV
text: function ggcorr plots correlation coefficients:  can display multiple correlation coefficients:  can compare two groups:  can compare two groups multiple correlation coefficients:  Specific functionality make appropriate plots concordance correlation coefficient available:  Text table can moved around resized:  Finally, text placement kept consistent axes visually transformed:
code: set.seed(3) response_vec_a <- rnorm(5) response_tbl <- data.frame(   group = rep(letters[1:3], each = 5),   response = c(     response_vec_a,     response_vec_a * 1.2 + rnorm(5, sd = 0.2),     response_vec_a * 2 + rnorm(5, sd = 2)   ),   pid = rep(paste0("id_", 1:5), 3) )  ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid" ) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = c("spearman", "pearson") ) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl,   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = "kendall" ) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl,   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = c("spearman", "pearson") ) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = "concordance",   abline = TRUE,   limits_equal = TRUE ) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::filter(group %in% c("a", "b")),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = c("spearman", "pearson", "concordance"),   abline = TRUE,   limits_equal = TRUE,   coord = c(0.4, 0.17),   font_size = 3,   skip = 0.04,   pval_signif = 2,   est_signif = 2,   ci_signif = 2 ) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl |> dplyr::mutate(response = abs(response + 1)^4),   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid",   corr_method = "spearman",   abline = TRUE,   limits_equal = TRUE,   trans = "log10",   skip = 0.06 )

title: UtilsGGSV
text: Fix axis limits equal x- y-axes, /expand axis coordinates. primary use axis_limits forcing x- y-axes limits “automatically” (.e. inspecting ggplot object, thus requiring user manually calculate limits pass ggplot2::expand_limits).
code: data("cars", package = "datasets")  p0 <- ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +   cowplot::background_grid(major = "xy") +   geom_point() +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) +   labs(title = "Axes unadjusted") +   labs(x = "Speed", y = "Distance") p1 <- axis_limits(   p = p0,   limits_equal = TRUE ) +   labs(title = "Axes limits equal") p2 <- axis_limits(   p = p0,   limits_expand = list(     x = c(0, 50),     y = c(-10, 200)   ) ) +   labs(title = "Axes limits expanded") cowplot::plot_grid(p0, p1, p2)

title: UtilsGGSV
text: Add column text easily plot, regardless underlying transformation, using add_text_column.  Note add_text_column places text position, regardless underlying transformation.
code: data_mod <- data.frame(x = rnorm(mean = 1, 10)^2) data_mod$y <- data_mod$x * 3 + rnorm(10, sd = 0.5) fit <- lm(y ~ x, data = data_mod) coef_tbl <- coefficients(summary(fit)) results_vec <- c(   paste0(     "Intercept: ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, "Estimate"][[1]], 2),     " (",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 1][[1]] - 2 * coef_tbl[1, 2][[1]], 3),     ", ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 1][[1]] + 2 * coef_tbl[1, 2][[1]], 3),     "; p = ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 4][[1]], 3),     ")"   ),   paste0(     "Slope: ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, "Estimate"][[1]], 2),     " (",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 1][[1]] - 2 * coef_tbl[2, 2][[1]], 3),     ", ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 1][[1]] + 2 * coef_tbl[2, 2][[1]], 3),     "; p = ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 4][[1]], 3),     ")"   ) ) p <- ggplot(   data = data_mod,   aes(x = x, y = y) ) +   geom_point() +   cowplot::background_grid(major = "xy")  add_text_column(   p = p,   x = data_mod$x,   y = data_mod$y,   text = results_vec,   coord = c(0.05, 0.95),   skip = 0.07 ) p <- p +   scale_y_continuous(     trans = UtilsGGSV::get_trans("asinh")   ) add_text_column(   p = p,   x = data_mod$x,   y = data_mod$y,   text = results_vec,   trans = UtilsGGSV::get_trans("asinh"),   coord = c(0.05, 0.95),   skip = 0.07 )

title: UtilsGGSV
text: utility function get_trans returns trans objects (implemented scales package) given characters. also adds various higher roots (cubic quartic) adds asinh transformation.
code: get_trans("log10") #> Transformer: log-10 [1e-100, Inf]

what: Add a column of text to a ggplot — add_text_column
title: Add a column of text to a ggplot — add_text_column
text: Adds column text ggplot object, overlaying text specified coordinates customizable transformation, font size, alignment.

title: Add a column of text to a ggplot — add_text_column
code: add_text_column(   p,   x,   y,   trans = "identity",   text,   coord = c(0.05, 0.95),   skip = 0.06,   font_size = 4.2,   hjust = 0,   vjust = 0.5,   ... )

title: Add a column of text to a ggplot — add_text_column
text: p ggplot object. Plot text overlaid onto. x, y numeric vector. min max vectors specify range plot. trans character trans object. Specifies (visual) transformation applied y-axis. Internally passed get_trans. Default "identity". Note transformation applied y-axis (assumption already ). text character vector. element specifies line text. Subsequent elements plotted underneath (assuming skip >= 0). coord numeric vector length two. elements specify x- y-coordinates, respectively, first line text (.e. first element) text. c(0, 0) means bottom-left corner c(1, 1) top-right. problem specifying values outside [0, 1], however. Default c(0.05, 0.95) (.e. towards top-left corner). skip numeric. Proportion y-axis length skip rows. Default 0.06. font_size numeric. Font size. Default 4.2 (roughly size 12). hjust, vjust numeric. Passed hjust vjust parameters geom_text. Defaults 0 0.5, respectively. ... Additional parameters passed geom_text.

title: Add a column of text to a ggplot — add_text_column
text: ggplot object added text.

title: Add a column of text to a ggplot — add_text_column
code: data_mod <- data.frame(x = rnorm(10)) data_mod$y <- data_mod$x * 3 + rnorm(10, sd = 0.5) fit <- lm(y ~ x, data = data_mod) coef_tbl <- coefficients(summary(fit)) results_vec <- c(   paste0(     "Intercept: ", signif(coef_tbl[1, "Estimate"][[1]], 2), " (",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 1][[1]] - 2 * coef_tbl[1, 2][[1]], 3), ", ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 1][[1]] + 2 * coef_tbl[1, 2][[1]], 3), "; p = ",     signif(coef_tbl[1, 4][[1]], 3), ")"   ),   paste0(     "Slope: ", signif(coef_tbl[2, "Estimate"][[1]], 2), " (",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 1][[1]] - 2 * coef_tbl[2, 2][[1]], 3), ", ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 1][[1]] + 2 * coef_tbl[2, 2][[1]], 3), "; p = ",     signif(coef_tbl[2, 4][[1]], 3), ")"   ) ) library(ggplot2) library(UtilsGGSV) p <- ggplot(data_mod, aes(x = x, y = y)) + geom_point() add_text_column(   p = p,   x = data_mod$x,   y = data_mod$y,   text = results_vec )   # Works even if y-axis is transformed p <- p + scale_y_continuous(trans = get_trans("asinh")) add_text_column(   p = p,   x = data_mod$x,   y = data_mod$y,   text = results_vec,   trans = "asinh" )

title: Manage axis limits — axis_limits
text: Manage axis limits. Fix axis limits equal x- y-axes, /expand axis coordinates. primary use axis_limits forcing x- y-axes limits "automatically" (.e. inspecting ggplot object, thus requiring user manually calculate limits pass ggplot2::expand_limits).

title: Manage axis limits — axis_limits
code: axis_limits(p, limits_expand = NULL, limits_equal = FALSE)

title: Manage axis limits — axis_limits
text: p object class 'ggplot'. Limits adjusted plot. limits_expand list. NULL, (effectively) passed onto ggplot2::expand_limits ensure certain values included plot (, example, 0 minimum value possible may plotted). named, # nolint must consist one numeric vector force values numeric value # nolint included plot. named, must names x /y, # nolint elements numeric vectors must included plot. limits_equal logical. TRUE, ranges x- y-axes # nolint must equal. Effectively applied expand_grid applied. Default FALSE. # nolint

title: Manage axis limits — axis_limits
code: data("cars", package = "datasets") library(ggplot2) p <- ggplot(cars, aes(speed, dist)) +   geom_point()  axis_limits(   p,   limits_equal = TRUE )   # both axes axis_limits(   p,   limits_expand = list(200) )  # x only axis_limits(   p,   limits_expand = list(x = 75) )  # y only axis_limits(   p,   limits_expand = list(y = 200) )  # lower and upper expansion axis_limits(   p,   limits_expand = list(     y = c(-50, 200),     x = c(-10, 75)   ) )   # note that when fixing range and expanding, range is fixed # after expansions are applied, so effectively the larger expansions apply to both. # compare the following output to the previous output: axis_limits(   p,   limits_expand = list(     y = c(-50, 200),     x = c(-10, 75)   ),   limits_equal = TRUE )

title: Get transformation object — get_trans
text: Converts character string specifying transformation trans object, returns input already trans object. Supports various root, log, transformations.

title: Get transformation object — get_trans
code: get_trans(trans)

title: Get transformation object — get_trans
text: trans character trans object. class character, converted trans object. Adds "root_cube", "root_fourth", "root_fifth" "asinh" transformations, well "sqrt" transformation allows plotting lines zero. class trans object, returned .

title: Get transformation object — get_trans
text: trans object corresponding specified transformation.

title: Get transformation object — get_trans
code: x_vec <- seq(1, 5, length.out = 1000) y_vec <- get_trans("root_fifth")$transform(x_vec) plot_tbl <- data.frame(x = x_vec, y = y_vec) library(ggplot2) ggplot(plot_tbl, aes(x, y)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   coord_equal() +   expand_limits(x = 5, y = 5)

what: Plot scatterplot with correlation coefficients and ab-line overlaid — ggcorr
title: Plot scatterplot with correlation coefficients and ab-line overlaid — ggcorr
text: Plots scatterplot various correlation coefficients optional ab-line overlaid.

title: Plot scatterplot with correlation coefficients and ab-line overlaid — ggcorr
code: ggcorr(   data,   corr_method = "spearman",   corr_lab = "auto",   grp,   grp_base = NULL,   grp_x = NULL,   grp_lab = "auto",   y,   id,   est_signif = 3,   ci = TRUE,   pval = TRUE,   ci_signif = 3,   pval_signif = 3,   pval_trunc = 0.001,   label_id = FALSE,   label_id_size = 3,   trans = "identity",   coord = c(0.05, 0.95),   skip = 0.05,   font_size = 4.2,   hjust = 0,   vjust = 0.5,   point_size = 1,   point_alpha = 0.9,   limits_expand = NULL,   limits_equal = FALSE,   legend_title = FALSE,   legend_position = "bottom",   thm = cowplot::theme_cowplot() + theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white")),   grid = cowplot::background_grid(major = "xy"),   grp_to_col = NULL,   abline = FALSE,   smooth = TRUE,   smooth_method = "lm",   smooth_se = FALSE )

title: Plot scatterplot with correlation coefficients and ab-line overlaid — ggcorr
text: data dataframe. Dataframe containing data plotted. corr_method character vector. Correlation method. One c("concordance", "pearson", "spearman", "kendall"). Default "spearman". corr_lab "never"``, "auto"“, "always" named character vector. Whether, , label correlation methods plot. "always" "never", correlation labels always never displayed, respectively. `"auto"`, displayed multiple correlation methods used. displaye dusing `"always"` `"never"`, default labels used. named character vector, names correlation methods values labels, e.g. `c("spearman" = "Spearman", "kendall" = "Kendall")`. Default `"auto"`. correlation methods used. grp character. Name column data specifies variables compare . first level within grp (.e. data[[grp]][1]) level plotted x-axis, unless grp_x set (see ). grp_base character. NULL, correlations level within data[[grp]] levels displayed. NULL, two-way correlations displayed. Default NULL. grp_x character. NULL, level grp plotted along x-axis. Default NULL. grp_lab "always", "auto" "never". Whether label groups compared specific displayed correlation coefficients. "always" "never", groups always never labelled, respectively. "auto", groups labelled multiple groups compared. Default "auto". y character. Name column data specifies values correlated groups. id character. Name column data specifies subject multiple measurements taken. est_signif numeric. Significant digits correlation estimates. Default 3. ci logical. Whether include confidence intervals correlation estimates. Default TRUE. pval logical. Whether include p-values correlation estimates. Default TRUE. ci_signif numeric. Significant digits confidence intervals. Default 3. pval_signif numeric. Significant digits p-values. Default 3. pval_trunc numeric. P-values smaller threshold displayed "< threshold". Default 0.001. label_id logical. TRUE, points labels given data[[id]] displayed using ggrepel::geom_text_repel. Default FALSE. label_id_size numeric. Size labels. Default 3. trans character trans object. Specifies scaling y- x-axes. class character, converted trans object. Adds "root_cube", "root_fourth", "root_fifth" "asinh" transformations, well "sqrt" transformation allows plotting lines zero. class trans object, returned . Default "identity". coord numeric vector. Coordinates text placement first () row results. Specified terms proportion axis length, first value specifying x-axis coordinate second value y-axis coordinate. Default c(0.05, 0.95), places first row top left corner plot. skip numeric. Proportion y-axis move lines text. Default 0.05. font_size numeric. Font size text results table. Default 10. hjust numeric. Horizontal justification text. Default 0. vjust numeric. Vertical justification text. Default 0.5. point_size numeric. Size points. Default 1. point_alpha numeric. Alpha value points. Default 0.9. limits_expand list. Expand axis limits. Default NULL. limits_equal logical. Set axis limits equal. Default FALSE. legend_title logical. FALSE, legend title removed. Default FALSE. legend_position character. Position legend. Default "bottom". NULL, legend's positioning jadjusted. thm ggplot2 theme. Specifies ggplot2 theme. Default cowplot::theme_cowplot(), white plot background (opposed transparent). grid value calling cowplot::background_grid. Specifies display grid lines. NULL, background grid displayed (recommended non-cowplot-themed plots). Default cowplot::background_grid(major = "xy"), displays major grid lines x- y-axes. grp_to_col character vector. Specifies colours elements grp. Elements colours. named, names specify level within grp colours matched. NULL two groups compared, points black. NULL two groups compared, defaults palette Set1 RColorBrewer package. Default NULL. abline logical. TRUE, y=x line plotted colour "gray85". Default TRUE. smooth logical. TRUE, linear regression line plotted. smooth_method character. Smoothing method pass geom_smooth. Default "lm". smooth_se logical. Whether display 95% confidence interval smooth line. Default FALSE.

title: Plot scatterplot with correlation coefficients and ab-line overlaid — ggcorr
code: response_vec_a <- rnorm(5) response_tbl <- data.frame(   group = rep(letters[1:3], each = 5),   response = c(     response_vec_a,     response_vec_a * 1.2 + rnorm(5, sd = 0.2),     response_vec_a * 2 + rnorm(5, sd = 2)   ),   pid = rep(paste0("id_", 1:5), 3) ) library(UtilsGGSV) ggcorr(   data = response_tbl,   grp = "group",   y = "response",   id = "pid" )

what: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::ggsave2 — ggsave2
title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::ggsave2 — ggsave2
text: Wrapper around cowplot::ggsave2 save plots multiple formats.

title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::ggsave2 — ggsave2
code: ggsave2(filename, plot, device = c("png", "pdf"), ...)

title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::ggsave2 — ggsave2
text: filename character. Name plot (including directory, save working directory). plot gg object. Output either ggplot2::ggplot cowplot::plot_grid. device character vector. Devices save (.e. plot format). Default c("png", "pdf"). ... passed cowplot::ggsave2.

title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::ggsave2 — ggsave2
text: invisible(filename).

what: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::save_plot — save_plot
title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::save_plot — save_plot
text: Wrapper around cowplot::save_plot save plots multiple formats.

title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::save_plot — save_plot
code: save_plot(filename, plot, device = c("png", "pdf"), ...)

title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::save_plot — save_plot
text: filename character. Name plot (including directory, save working directory). plot gg object. Output either ggplot2::ggplot cowplot::plot_grid. device character vector. Devices save (.e. plot format). Default c("png", "pdf"). ... passed cowplot::save_plot.

title: Save plot in multiple formats using cowplot::save_plot — save_plot
text: invisible(filename).
